This report was prepared by  a team from South Asia Department Social Sectors Division 
consisting of S. A. Khan, Team Leader and Urban Development Specialist; L. Gutierrez, Project 
Economist; and E.M. Mayerhofer, Environment Specialist

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Rawalpindi is the third largest city in Pakistan and currently has over 1.5 million people, 
with about 4% annual growth. About 40% of the city’s population is in the low income group. To 
address  the  problems  of  scarcity  of  safe  drinking  water  and  poor  drainage,  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) approved a loan of $72 million in 1993 for the Rawalpindi Urban 
Water Supply and Sanitation Project, which forms the first phase of a proposed 3-phase 
program for improving the water and sanitation services in Rawalpindi.1 At the completion of the 
first phase of the program in 2003, Rawalpindi will have increased water supplies from 192,000 
cubic meter per day (cmd) to the planned 256,000 cmd, with considerable rehabilitation and 
extension of its water supply distribution network and an improved drainage system. In addition, 
major  institutional  and  financial  reforms  have  been  successfully  implemented  and,  the 
engineering studies for the future development of water supplies, sewerage and drainage 
master plans, and a solid waste management plan have been prepared under the phase I 
project. The second phase of the program is conceived to focus on further improvements to 
sewerage  and  drainage,  the  provision  of  a  sewage  treatment  plant,  and  solid  waster 
management. The third phase will complete the overall requirements in Rawalpindi's water and 
sanitation sector.  
 
 2.  The Government of Pakistan requested ADB in December 2002 for financial assistance 
for a second phase of the ongoing program. In response, ADB fielded from 15 to 26 February 
2003  the  Fact-Finding  Mission  for  the  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (TA).  The 
Mission conducted extensive field visits in the project area in Rawalpindi, met with the officials 
from federal and  provincial governments, and with the Rawalpindi District and subdistrict 
(tehsil) governments. Consultative meetings were held with the beneficiary groups, elected 
female councilors of Rawalpindi district, nongovernment organizations (NGOs), and the related 
bilateral agencies. The Mission presented its findings to the government who concurred with the 
goals, purpose, scope, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms 
of reference of the consultants for the TA.2 The proposed Project will be in line with the 
Government’s Ten Year Perspective Development Plan 2001–2011 to improve social services 
in the country and accelerate gains in productivity; reduce poverty; and promote smaller, 
healthier, and better educated families. ADB's Country Strategy and Program for Pakistan 
(2002–2006) reaffirms ADB’s assistance to the government for improving municipal services in 
the context of devolving municipal functions to local governments, with particular focus on 
services for the poor. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Lack of Adequate Water Supply. The water supply available to Rawalpindi City does 
not reach the planned 256,000 cmd  due to the poor yield from Khanpur Dam and decreasing 
outflows from existing tubewells, mainly due to persistent drought over the past 3 years.  The 
city is expected to face future deficits of about 27% of demand in 2010 and 48% in 2025.3 The 
projected deficits may be addressed through (i) reducing water loss, which accounts for over 
30% of treated water production, in the mains and distribution network, (ii) introducing water 
conservation measures to reduce demand and (iii) developing new water supply sources.

2  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities (Internet edtition) on 21 January 2003.

2 
Regarding new water sources, the Rawalpindi Water and Sanitation Agency (WASA) and the 
Small Dams Organization (SDO) have prepared proposals for developing small storage dams 
surrounding Rawalpindi. Comprehensive technical, economic, and financial studies  of these 
proposals have yet to be undertaken.    
    
4.  Poor Water Quality. Water quality analyses done in 20024 showed that over 85% of 
water samples analyzed for physical, chemical, and bacteriological parameters were found 
unsafe for human consumption due to bacterial contamination. The distribution system is weak 
due to intermittent water supply, leakage, and ingress of pollution from sewerage pipes and 
storm drains. WASA has recently installed some chlorination facilities at selected tubewells, but 
many tubewells have no disinfection facilities.  In addition, a preliminary study by the phase I 
project consultants identified significant sources of pollution within the Rawal Lake Catchment, 
which feeds Rawalpindi. The Rawal Lake Catchment management plan was prepared under the 
phase I project, but has not yet been implemented. A comprehensive sampling and analysis 
program for the existing distribution network is needed to determine baseline quality levels, 
followed by necessary study for cost effective quality enhancement; and the proposed Rawal 
Lake Catchment management plan should be reviewed and assisted to enforce control of 
pollution from municipal, industrial, agricultural, and other developments within the catchment.    
    
5.  Limited Sewerage Coverage. The sewerage system of Rawalpindi presently serves 
only about 30% of the population and some of this is ineffective because of blockages and poor 
maintenance.5 Raw sewage, which discharges through piped or open channel systems into the 
nearest drains, cause serious public health and environmental problems.  Considerable work is 
required to connect properties to the existing system, by further developing the area sewerage 
and house connections network. Construction of trunk sewers, as per the sewerage master 
plan, and the connection of all primary/secondary sewers to these trunk sewers, will help reduce 
serious health hazards. 
    
6.  Absence  of  Sewage  Treatment  and  Consequent  Environmental  and  Health 
Hazards.  No sewage treatment facility is available for Rawalpindi municipal or industrial 
wastewaters, which discharge into storm water drains.  To safeguard public health and the 
environment and avoid flooding in the drains, all sewage should eventually be collected and 
piped through a new outfall sewer to a safe disposal location. 
   
7.  Poor Condition of Stormwater Drainage. The urban drainage system, particularly to 
the east of the city, is in very poor condition, having been neglected for many years.  In some 
areas, the system is undersized, restricted by encroachments and crossings, and blocked with 
solid waste and other debris.  Major flooding occurs along these drains in each monsoon 
season.  Upstream of the catchments, is a network of tertiary drains that are polluted by sewage 
and septic tank discharges, animal waste, and municipal solid waste.  Under the phase I project, 
the main drain through the city—Lai Nullah, is being extensively upgraded to remove blockages 
and improve hydraulic capacity.  However, the major tributaries to the Lai Nullah, such as Kassi 
East and Kassi West, are not covered by these works and significant cleaning and rehabilitation 
work is necessary to reduce flood potential and improve the environment.   
 
8.  Solid Waste Management. Lack of an organized solid waste management system in 
the  city  has  been  a  major  contributor  to  environmental  pollution.  The  Tehsil  Municipal 
Administration  (TMA)  has  reportedly  made  some  progress  with  secondary  collection  and

5 Urban Water Supply and Sanitation Project, Rawalpindi, Phase II Concept Report, 2002.

3 
disposal following initiatives funded by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) 
and Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA), and a new site has been purchased, for a 
sanitary landfill of 30 hectares at some distance from the city.  NGOs have also started some 
community-led  primary  collection  initiatives.    The  major  issues  that  urgently  need  to  be 
addressed are provision of a transfer station, development of the sanitary landfill site, safe 
disposal of hospital waste, and improvement of the community-led primary collection. Further, 
the improvement in the overall solid waste management for sustained and efficient operations is 
a  major  challenge  that  can  be  addressed  through  techniques  such  as  public-private 
partnerships together with strengthening the TMAs. 
 
9.  Institutional  Strengthening.  Under  the  phase  I  project,  some  major  financial  and 
institutional  reforms  were  implemented  and  WASA  staff  received  training.  As  a  result, 
considerable improvement in financial management was achieved and in 1999 WASA started 
generating  more  revenues  than  expenditures  (Appendix  1).  The  progress  toward  self-
sustainability by WASA must be maintained and improved through proper and effective tariff 
structures and revenue collection. In view of the recent devolution of the overall control of 
WASA  to  the  TMA,  it  is  essential  to  (i)  review  the  proposed  institutional  and  financial 
arrangements to ensure sustainable operations in water supply, sewerage, drainage, and solid 
waste management; and (ii) ensure that the revised tariff plan, as agreed under the phase 1 
project, is implemented according to the agreed schedule.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
10.  The overall purpose of the proposed Project is to improve living conditions and the 
quality of life of and reduce poverty among the people in Rawalpindi, where available water is 
inadequate to meet basic needs and environmental conditions are hazardous due to inadequate 
sewerage, drainage, and solid waste management facilities. The TA will prepare a Project that 
is suitable for ADB financing. The Project will facilitate sustainable urban development in the city 
and slum areas, alleviate water shortage, and address severe environmental problems faced by 
poor urban communities. The TA will also prepare recommendations for strengthening the TMA 
and  WASA  for  sustainable  operation  of  the  municipal  functions  under  the  government's 
devolution plan. 
 
11.  The  TA  will  provide  the  overall  project  design,  scope,  cost,  financing  plan, 
implementation arrangements, and will formulate the terms of reference for the consultants to 
be recruited to implement the Project. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The TA will be implemented in two phases: phase 1—situation analysis, and phase II—
preparation of the proposed Rawalpindi Environmental Improvement Project. The situation 
analysis will include (i) a review of the master plans of the infrastructure development for water 
supply, drainage, and sewerage; sewage treatment; and solid waste collection and disposal, 
prepared during the phase-I project; (ii) an evaluation of the technical sustainability of the 
phase-I project works, including the efficiency of the extended capacity of the Rawal Lake 
filtration plant and the leakage detection and rectification program proposed to nullify loss of 
water through leakages from the system, and an assessment of the scope of rehabilitation of 
the water distribution system not covered under the phase-I project; (iii) a critical evaluation of 
the  quality  of  water  supplied,  and  preparation  of  recommendations;  (iv)  a  review  of  the

4 
adequacy of existing water supply and sewerage records for proper asset maintenance; (v) a 
review of the TMA's solid waste management practices, and a management audit to ensure 
efficient collection and safe disposal; (vi) a review of the initiatives of community organizations, 
including the gender groups to improve local area environment; (vii) a review of the conditions in 
low income communities and an assessment of poverty and environment infrastructure; and 
(viii) a review of the institutional capacity of TMA and WASA, and recommended actions for their 
strengthening to ensure the sustainability of overall operations of municipal functions and that of 
financial reforms implemented for WASA under the phase 1 project.  Project preparation will 
include  development  of  community  participation;  formulation  of  priority  infrastructure;  
institutional  arrangements;  and    preparation  of  an  environmental  infrastructure  investment 
program, with integrated urban development works. 
 
13.  Project interventions will specifically focus on low-income communities. The Project will 
be prepared using community participation, including women’s groups, and involving, wherever 
feasible and appropriate, implementation through community-based organizations. The TA will 
review governance issues relating to beneficiary and local government participation, especially 
the devolution of powers to local governments, to (i) increase ownership, transparency, and 
accountability; and (ii) over the longer term, create an institutional framework that will increase 
empowerment  and  strengthen  social  capital.  The  summary  poverty  reduction  and  social 
analysis is in Appendix 2. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $438,000 equivalent, comprising $217,000 in 
foreign exchange and $221,000 equivalent in local currency costs. ADB will finance the entire 
foreign exchange cost and $133,000 equivalent of the local currency cost, totaling $350,000 
equivalent on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The government will provide $88,000 
equivalent to cover the remuneration of counterpart staff, provision of office accommodation and 
facilities,  field  surveys,  local  transportation  for  counterpart  staff,  and  funds  for  workshop 
activities. The details of the cost estimates and financing arrangements are in Appendix 3. The 
government has been advised that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any 
ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The  Housing,  Urban  Development  and  Public  Health  Engineering  Department 
(HUDPHED) of the Government of Punjab, and the Rawalpindi TMA will be the executing 
agencies for the TA. The deputy managing director of WASA will be the TA coordinator, who will 
be supported by five senior engineers and administrative support staff to work full time with the 
consultants.  Overall  guidance  for  TA  implementation  will  be  provided  through  a  steering 
committee to be chaired by the secretary, HUDPHED, with the Rawalpindi Tehsil head, and 
director  general  of  Rawalpindi  Development  Authority  as  vice  chairmen,  and  with 
representatives from TMA, WASA, key project management unit staff of the phase I project, 
capital  development  authority,  and  SDO,  as  members.  The  steering  committee  will  meet 
monthly.  
 
16.  The TA will require about 37.5 person-months of consulting services, comprising 8 
person-months  of  international  and  27.5  person-months  of  domestic  consultants  in  urban 
development; water supply, sanitation, and drainage; solid waste management; sewerage and 
sewage  treatment;  storm  water  drainage;  asset  management;  institutional  development; 
sociology and gender, resettlement, environment, economics, and finance. The TA will be

5 
undertaken by a firm to be recruited in accordance with the quality-and cost-based selection 
method of ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to 
ADB for the engagement of domestic consultants. The consultants will be requested to submit 
simplified technical proposals. Outline terms of reference for consulting services are provided in 
Appendix 4. The consultants will procure equipment through direct purchase, in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement.  
 
17.  The TA will be implemented over 5 months, during July 2003 to November 2003. The 
consultants  will  submit  the  following  reports:  (i)  a  brief  inception  report,  2  weeks  after 
commencing the services; (ii) an interim report, at the end of 2.5 months; (iii) a draft final report, 
at the end of the 4th month from start of the TA; and (iv) a final report, 2 weeks after receipt of 
comments on the draft final report from the Government of Punjab and ADB. The TA will include 
two workshops, one after the submission of the inception report and another after the interim 
report.  The  workshops  will  be  an  opportunity  to  contribute  to  the  planning  process  to 
representatives of concerned agencies of Punjab and central government, the general public, 
male  and  female  community  groups,  NGOs,  and  private  sector  organizations.  Tripartite 
meetings will be held with the government, ADB, and the consultants following the submission 
of each report. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $350,000 to the Government 
of  Pakistan  for  preparing  the  Rawalpindi  Environmental  Improvement  Project,  and  hereby 
reports this action to the Board. The technical assistance, initially financed as a grant, will be 
subject to the reimbursement arrangements set forth in Technical Assistance Operations6 and 
Streamlining of Technical Assistance Operations.7 If the technical assistance results in an ADB 
loan, ADB may charge against the loan, and recover from it, the portion of the initial grant that 
exceeds $250,000 equivalent.

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in Pakistan: 
 
Lack of water scarcity impacts  the lowest income groups, especially women and children who spend 
much time fetching water causing the women to lose out on productive opportunities while children loose 
out on educational opportunities. These people also suffer significantly from water-borne diseases and the 
high cost of heath care due to illness. Provision of clean water will enable these beneficiaries to make 
more productive use of their time and will provide significantly health benefits.    
B.  Poverty Analysis    Proposed Classification: Poverty Reduction 
The Benefit Monitoring & Evaluation system established under phase-I project will continue functioning 
as PPMS under the Project. This system will help in assessing the status of poverty profile during the 
Project period. The poverty analyses will be based on income and access-to-opportunities criteria. 
C.  Participation Process 
Stakeholder Analysis: 
Key stakeholders will include the elected councilors (representatives of male and female communities 
groups),  tehsil  municipal  administration,  district  government,  provincial  line  departments,  active  non 
government organizations and external support agencies. All of them will be meaningfully involved in 
project preparation, implementation, and project performance management system. During the technical 
assistance (TA), two consultative workshops will be conducted, one at the inception stage and other 
following the submission of interim report.  
 
Participation Strategy: 
The strategy will be prepared during the TA.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.   The consultants will work closely with the staff of the Rawalpindi Water and Sanitation 
Agency (WASA) and the Rawalpindi Tehsil Municipal Administration (TMA), and will coordinate 
with low-income communities, community-based organizations, nongovernmental organizations 
(NGOS), civil society, and the private sector, to foster a high level of local ownership of the 
project preparatory technical assistance (TA). The consultants are also required to coordinate 
closely with other funding agencies involved in community participatory approaches with poor 
communities, and to review relevant available documents, reports, and other reference material 
that are available from these initiatives, especially lessons learned from previous urban sector 
projects. Particular focus needs to be given to the lessons learned from the phase I project and, 
ongoing initiatives such as the Orangi Pilot Project approach and Program for Improvement in 
the Livelihood of Urban Slums which is funded by the United Nations Development Programme 
(UNDP)  and  is  being  implemented  in  the  cities  of  Faisalabad,  Gujranawala, Lodhran, and 
Multan. Of specific interest are documents prepared by the UNDP-World Bank Water and 
Sanitation Program (“Selection of the Strategic Sanitation Approach Pilot in Southern Punjab, 
August 1999,” “Municipal Management and Finance in Southern Punjab,” and “A Comparative 
Study of Four Municipalities, October 1999”), ongoing Asian Development Bank (ADB) TA for 
the Southern Punjab Basic Urban Services Project. In the preparation of social assessments, 
the consultants will use the ADB Guidelines for the Incorporation of Social Dimensions in Bank 
Operations and the  Handbook for Incorporation of Social Dimensions in Projects. Any initial 
environmental examination (IEE) required for proposed project components will be prepared in 
accordance with  ADB's Environment Policy, Operations Manual Section 20,  Environmental 
Considerations  in  ADB  Operations,  and  the  Environmental  Guidelines  for  Selected 
Infrastructure  Projects,  1993.  Reference  should  also  be  made  to  ADB  studies  including 
Pakistan:  Country  Environmental  Policy  Integration  Study;  Pakistan:  Environmental 
Management  Strategy  Report;  and  Pakistan:  Natural  Resources  and  the  Environmental 
Management. For economic and financial analysis of the Project, the consultants will use ADB 
Guidelines for the  Economic Analysis of Projects (1997), Framework for the Economic and 
Financial Appraisal of Urban Development Sector Projects (1994), and  Guidelines for the 
Financial Analysis of Projects. The table summarizes the times estimated for the consultants’ 
services.
